Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The effects of soil moisture on fungal weathering, diversity, and abundance.
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

A non-technical description explaining the broader significance of the project

Soil is arguably the most important physical resource that exists at the Earth's surface. It is essential for the growth and development of our food supply and soils help regulate the composition of the atmosphere. Despite this central role, knowledge of the processes of soil formation is still very rudimentary. Microbial activity has a principal role in breaking down rocks into fertile soil and identifying the major mechanisms and types of microorganisms is an ongoing research activity. Fungi are a class of these microbes that have received little attention, but likely are very important contributors to soil generation. This project will take a close look at the abundance and distribution of fungi in soils, their activity as a function of moisture availability, and the possible role they play in soil formation under a variety of climatic conditions.

A technical description of the project

This project will explore the relationship between moisture content of soils and fungal weathering of igneous rocks, estimate fungal weathering rates, and identify and quantify the fungal community. The study will examine responses of the fungal community to decreasing soil moisture content (drought) and the processes facilitated by mycorrhizal fungi to help plants cope with water stress. These will be tested by collecting soil samples along a climate gradient, and then interrogate these samples by using DNA and aquaporin (integral membrane proteins) analyses, and microscopic and spectroscopic techniques. The project will use the Catalina-Jemez Critical Zone Observatories and the Landscape Evolution Observatory at Biosphere 2 of University of Arizona, which provide opportunities to study processes along a climate gradient. Four undergraduates from a Primarily Undergraduate Institution will assist with the project and the results will be used to augment general science education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current climate change models predict an increase in the occurrence and magnitude of droughts for a large portion of the globe and for nearly 1/5th of the US. The increasing droughts will reduce soil moisture and most likely impact the soil microbial and fungal community, thus their weathering (mineral transformation) potential. Previous research showed that symbiotic fungi are able to reach soil water pools that are inaccessible to plants and help the plants survive moderate droughts. In addition, we also understand that water availability influences the nutrient and carbon dynamics in soil ecosystems and contribute to the effectiveness of biological weathering. Researchers have monitored changes in soil moisture, but our understanding of the response of fungal communities to changing moisture content is still limited.

The overarching goal of this study was to explore the relationship between moisture content of soils and fungal weathering of igneous rocks as it influences soil formation and other geochemical processes in soils of the Santa Catalina Mountains Critical Zone Observatory and the basalt of the Landscape Evolution Observatory of Biosphere 2 in Tucson, AZ. The PI hypothesized that fungal community structure shifts to more drought tolerant species, the expression of aquaporin (water transport protein) in fungi increases and fungal diversity decreases with decreasing moisture content. In addition, symbiotic fungal associations under higher water stress facilitate a larger portion of water and nutrient acquisition, thus, the contribution of fungi to overall weathering is expected to increase from wetter toward drier sites along the climate gradient.

Soil samples were collected along the climate gradient in the Santa Catalina Mountains Critical Zone Observatory and small basalt samples were obtained from the Landscape Evolution Observatory sample archives. The collaborating team of undergraduate student researchers along with the PI analyzed subsamples of each collected sample using various modes of scanning electron microscopy equipped with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy, and electron microprobe equipped with wavelength dispersive spectroscopy. The team also processed samples for DNA, RNA and aquaporin analysis.

The study has shown that symbiotic fungi and associated bacteria can promote chemical dissolution of soil minerals, and are able to produce organo-clay coatings and stimulate secondary mineral formation on grain surfaces under natural soil forming conditions. Microscopy results confirmed strong attachment of fungi to mineral surfaces at the mid- and high-elevation sites and a high degree of etching on feldspar grains at all sites. The measured DNA concentrations showed the presence of microbes and fungi at all sites. Total DNA concentration decreased from top to bottom in each soil profile, and from the wetter toward the drier site, which was expected. However, a clear connection between moisture availability and fungal weathering could not be established at the field site due to high variations and large uncertainties of the obtained results.

The micro- and nano-scale investigation of the basalt grains of the Landscape Evolution Observatory revealed that 3-4 years of incipient soil formation under a dry climate without the systematic introduction of any biology is too short time to produce quantifiable amounts of secondary minerals and surface alteration of basalt grains. However, the basalt surfaces changed over time, the amount of small-adhered particles decreased, and dissolved features somewhat increased compared to the initial basalt. Formation of secondary coatings was observed, but they were too small to determine their chemical composition. The proportion of amorphous material within basalt samples did not change significantly, and there was only a small amount of microbial material observed on the grain surfaces.

These results encouraged the setup of a controlled and simplified laboratory experiment with known fungal species, aquaporin sequence, and varying moisture availability to be able to test whether fungi responding to moisture limitations via regulating their aquaporin production and activity. This study provided insight to improve the understanding of microbial and fungal attachment to mineral surfaces in drought-prone soil environments. Ultimately, this type of work has the potential to provide information for improving plant nutrition and soil sustainability under decreasing moisture availability.
